pageContext.claim: “But -- but I have to say that people were coming up to me, strong people, tough people with businesses that were 100-years-old, people that were pillars of their community, and they had tears in their eyes of what Cordray was doing. He was putting them out of business. He was actually putting them out of business.”
pageContext.analysis: Richard Cordray, who is the Democratic nominee to become governor of Ohio, led the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) until November of 2017. Cordray’s turbulent six-year tenure at the 1,600-person agency was marked by aggressive efforts to rein in banks, payday lenders and debt collectors that often drew protests from the business community, but Trump's claim that it forced 100-year-old businesses to close is a stretch. The bureau aimed to regulate business practices that preyed on consumers.
